title: Mow this lawn. Learn about your brain.
description: Your lawn mowing style says more about you than you think.

If we abstract away the mowing, itâ€™s really just a path formed by connecting nodes. You were X% less efficient than the optimal path, which looks like this:The optimal path looks like this:
Surprisingly, most humans are actually really good at finding solutions to pathfinding problems like this. The most popular example is the Traveling Salesman Problem.

value.figcaption: From The Coding Train with Daniel Shiffman

content.value: The premise is simple: a salesperson must visit a set of cities exactly once and return to their starting point, all while taking the shortest possible route. We see this all the time in the real world. From a pizza delivery driver planning their stops to a trick-or-treater maximizing their candy haul, finding the most efficient routes would be solving a version of this problem.

I read a study that found humans come impressively close to computer-calculated optimal solutions to this problem with fewer stops, and even do pretty good — just 11% less efficient than optimal — for 70+ stops.

value.alt: A chart depicting how people perform on the Traveling Salesman Problem compared to the optimal path, which shows that people perform near-ideal at fewer nodes, with a slow increasing deviation as more nodes are added
value.figcaption: Chart of findings from this study

content.value: I was curious; how well might humans perform on a similar optimization problem?

But first, a very quick computer science primer. There are two main ways to tackle problems like these: algorithms that calculate the optimal path and heuristicsâ€”simple strategies for completing the task.

Algorithms solve the problem with an estimated optimal solution. But that can come at a cost as complexity grows. For example, brute force calculations for a salesperson visiting just 10 cities requires testing 3.6 million possible routes, and that number explodes exponentially as more cities are added.

Heuristics are a lot like human problem-solving; they aim for a good-enough strategy that solves the problem quickly. For example, choosing the closest city at each step isnâ€™t perfect, but itâ€™s much faster and usually close to the optimal route.
For our experiment, weâ€™ll stick with heuristics.

We chose to look at seven different heuristics for our lawn mower game, which is a problem more formally called Coverage Path Planning. To focus on your path planning vs. driving skills, we simplified the world into a grid of cells.
